Feature.Name: Ray Tracing
Feature.Description: In computer graphics, ray tracing is a rendering technique for generating an image by tracing the path of light as pixels in an image plane and simulating the effects of its encounters with virtual objects.

Feature.Description: In computer graphics, ray tracing is a rendering technique for generating an image by tracing the path of light as pixels in an image plane and simulating the effects of its encounters with virtual objects.

Feature.Name: Rasterisation
Feature.Description: Rasterisation (or rasterization) is the task of taking an image described in a vector graphics format (shapes) and converting it into a raster image (pixels or dots) for output on a video display or printer, or for storage in a bitmap file format.

Feature.Name: Text core
Feature.Description: Text games were actually better than what came after them for some time, but it took centuries for people to notice and by then everyone had become a book called "?". More seriously: text is the core of any game.

Feature.Name: Single Playscreen
Feature.Description: Yup. Literally just one screen. That's the entire game. Probably also monochrome.

Feature.Name: 2D rendering
Feature.Description: Everyone loves double D. Maybe even with colour.

Feature.Name: Wireframe 3D
Feature.Description: Triple your D, but early. There are colours.

Feature.Name: 3D rendering
Feature.Description: Triple your D but now with other stuff filling the stuff so it's much more stuff than before. COLOURS EVERYWHERE

Feature.Name: GAPI Integration
Feature.Description: Hook into the OS' 2D and 3D graphics API and leverage driver capabilities for a superior end-user experience. tl;dr more pretty

Feature.Name: AGAPI Integration
Feature.Description: Hook into the OS' 2D and 3D "advanced" graphics API and leverage driver capabilities for a superior end-user experience. tl;dr even more pretty

Feature.Name: HAPI Integration
Feature.Description: Hook into the OS' 2D and 3D holographic API and leverage driver capabilities for a superior end-user experience. tl;dr holodecks

Feature.Name: Single-channel audio
Feature.Description: Just Crackle.

Feature.Name: Dual-channel audio
Feature.Description: No, not Crackle and Pop. Hopefully.

Feature.Name: 8-bit audio
Feature.Description: Eventually, simply awe.

Feature.Name: HD audio
Feature.Description: Many bits in your awww.

Feature.Name: Sequential Events
Feature.Description: A. B. C. D. Not always as boring as it sounds here.

Feature.Name: Event Scripting
Feature.Description: This allows things to happen because of stuff, instead of things to happen just in sequences. Essentially this allows for more dynamic level designs - at simplest, like doors that open when the user wants them to, or when more complex, like a wall that catches fire because someone threw a Molotov cocktail.

Feature.Name: Branching Event Trees
Feature.Description: Allowing all kinds of branching events and their integration into both game logic and UI - including dialogues. Shakespeare but possibly with monkeys.

Feature.Name: Simple Physics
Feature.Description: What! Why apple go fally!

Feature.Name: Advanced Physics
Feature.Description: e=mc^2
